thread.title: Attorney General Wants Answers On CT Residents Being Denied Rental Cars In Florida
thread.title_full: Attorney General Wants Answers On CT Residents Being Denied Rental Cars In Florida

author: Donald Eng
title: Attorney General Wants Answers On CT Residents Being Denied Rental Cars In Florida
text:
HARTFORD, CT – With state school districts going into spring break this month, many Connecticut residents are heading out of state, including to Florida. But upon arriving in the Sunshine State, some Connecticut residents have been dismayed to learn that their reservations for rental cars would not be honored, even after they paid a deposit and submitted payment information.
The Office of Attorney General William Tong on Wednesday sent a letter to the Avis Budget Group following complaints that vehicle rental locations in Florida may be improperly refusing service to licensed Connecticut drivers.
The websites of Avis, Budget, and Payless suggest that they will refuse to rent vehicles to Connecticut consumers in Florida if they have certain Connecticut driver licenses, including licenses imprinted with “Not for Federal Identification,” claiming such licenses are “not valid for identification purposes” and not “recognized by the State of Florida to drive a vehicle on public roads.”
These statements appear only on FAQ pages on the Avis, Budget, and Payless websites but do not appear to be prominently displayed to consumers when making vehicle reservations or providing personal information or payment details.
The Avis website in question contains the following statement:
“Certain, limited out-of-state licenses are not, pursuant to state law, recognized by the State of Florida to drive a vehicle on public roads. These licenses are not valid for identification purposes and will have a statement similar to:
- Not For Federal Identification
- Driving Privilege Only
- Not Valid for Identification
“This policy applies to any state that issues this type of driver’s license, including Connecticut & Delaware.”
Assistant Attorney General Joseph Gasser stated in the letter that these denials of service to Connecticut drivers with licenses imprinted “Not for Federal Identification” appear to be based on a misapplication of Florida Statute § 322-033(2), which purports to reject “licenses issued by another state exclusively to undocumented immigrants.”
Gasser stated that such licenses had been issued since at least 2011 “to Connecticut residents who are citizens or otherwise documented residents of the United States. They are valid driver licenses and are not ‘issued by another state exclusively to undocumented immigrants.’”
Gasser requested information from Avis Budget on its policies related to Connecticut licenses, disclosures provided to consumers, and complaints from Connecticut consumers.

Attorney General William Tong, alongside a coalition of 22 other state attorneys general, has urged the U.S. House of Representatives to reject a resolution that would overturn a key 2024 rule from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) aimed at curbing what they called excessive overdraft fees charged by major banks.

HARTFORD, CT – The Public Health Committee voted to send House Bill 7215 to the floor of the House on Wednesday to address problem gambling, particularly as it relates to internet gaming disorder, which has surged since the state legalized online sports betting and casino gaming in 2021.
